title: Elizabeth Warren Raises $8.67 Million for Massachusetts Senate Race
content:
BOSTON – Elizabeth Warren , the Democratic candidate in the closely watched Senate race in Massachusetts , raised $ 8.67 million in the second quarter of this year , according to her campaign .
The impressive total is the biggest quarterly haul yet for Ms. Warren , who has so far raised more money than any Congressional candidate in the nation , according to OpenSecrets.org , which collects campaign finance data . Ms. Warren raised nearly $ 5.7 million in the fourth quarter of 2011 , and $ 6.9 million in the first quarter of this year .
The new numbers suggest that Ms. Warren ’ s fund-raising ability was not marred at the end of April , when the campaign struggled to defend itself against months of questions , sometimes stoked by the campaign of her opponent , Senator Scott P. Brown , a Republican , over whether she had claimed Native-American ancestry to advance her career .
Ms. Warren ’ s campaign said that $ 3.1 million was raised in June alone , and that 81 percent of the quarter ’ s donations came in increments of $ 50 or less . There were also big-name fund-raisers , like a May event hosted in Hollywood by the film stars Ben Affleck and Matt Damon , which raised over $ 250,000 .
The campaign now has $ 13.5 million on hand , it said .
“ Elizabeth Warren has fought hard to create a level playing field for middle-class families , ” Ms. Warren ’ s campaign manager , Mindy Myers , said in a statement , adding , “ We still have a long way to go until Nov. 6 , and Wall Street and other powerful interests are going to continue to send their millions to Scott Brown . ”
Responding to news of the tally , Mr. Brown ’ s campaign said Ms. Warren is “ largely dependent out-of-state , extreme special interests , ” in a statement by Alleigh Marre , a campaign spokeswoman . She continued , “ No amount of money can wash away Professor Warren ’ s support of job-crushing tax hikes that would devastate our economy , especially in the wake of Friday ’ s incredibly weak employment report . ”
In an e-mail to supporters , Ms. Warren ’ s campaign said it has received donations from 40,500 individuals from Massachusetts , but the campaign did not immediately release information about the breakdown between in- and out-of-state donors .
Ms. Warren is locked in a close race with Mr. Brown , who has not yet released his second-quarter fund-raising totals . She has outraised him in each quarter of the campaign so far , although his total war chest of about $ 15 million exceeded hers at the end of this year ’ s first quarter by about $ 4 million , helped by money raised for his special election in 2010 .
content_original:
BOSTON – Elizabeth Warren, the Democratic candidate in the closely watched Senate race in Massachusetts, raised $8.67 million in the second quarter of this year, according to her campaign.

The impressive total is the biggest quarterly haul yet for Ms. Warren, who has so far raised more money than any Congressional candidate in the nation, according to OpenSecrets.org, which collects campaign finance data. Ms. Warren raised nearly $5.7 million in the fourth quarter of 2011, and $6.9 million in the first quarter of this year.

The new numbers suggest that Ms. Warren’s fund-raising ability was not marred at the end of April, when the campaign struggled to defend itself against months of questions, sometimes stoked by the campaign of her opponent, Senator Scott P. Brown, a Republican, over whether she had claimed Native-American ancestry to advance her career.

Ms. Warren’s campaign said that $3.1 million was raised in June alone, and that 81 percent of the quarter’s donations came in increments of $50 or less. There were also big-name fund-raisers, like a May event hosted in Hollywood by the film stars Ben Affleck and Matt Damon, which raised over $250,000.

The campaign now has $13.5 million on hand, it said.

“Elizabeth Warren has fought hard to create a level playing field for middle-class families,” Ms. Warren’s campaign manager, Mindy Myers, said in a statement, adding, “We still have a long way to go until Nov. 6, and Wall Street and other powerful interests are going to continue to send their millions to Scott Brown.”

Responding to news of the tally, Mr. Brown’s campaign said Ms. Warren is “largely dependent out-of-state, extreme special interests,” in a statement by Alleigh Marre, a campaign spokeswoman. She continued, “No amount of money can wash away Professor Warren’s support of job-crushing tax hikes that would devastate our economy, especially in the wake of Friday’s incredibly weak employment report.”

In an e-mail to supporters, Ms. Warren’s campaign said it has received donations from 40,500 individuals from Massachusetts, but the campaign did not immediately release information about the breakdown between in- and out-of-state donors.

Ms. Warren is locked in a close race with Mr. Brown, who has not yet released his second-quarter fund-raising totals. She has outraised him in each quarter of the campaign so far, although his total war chest of about $15 million exceeded hers at the end of this year’s first quarter by about $4 million, helped by money raised for his special election in 2010.
